Crime_Name: Tax Penalty and Interest Waiver Request
Dispute_Type: Tax penalty and interest relief denial
Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Minister's decision to deny penalty and interest relief
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient medical evidence provided for ADHD claim
Decision_Outcome: Denial of penalty and interest waiver request
Burden_of_Proof: On taxpayer to justify exceptional circumstances
Credibility_Factor: Lack of sufficient medical documentation supporting ADHD
Legal_Rule: Minister may waive or cancel penalties or interest if circumstances justify it under section 220(3.1)
Procedural_Issue: Application for judicial review of administrative decision
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Decision made in good faith and based on relevant factors
Key_Evidence_Considered: Taxpayer's compliance history, medical evidence (or lack thereof) for ADHD
Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles, statutory discretion under Income Tax Act
Applicant_Challenge: Challenge to denial of penalty and interest relief
Legal_Rule_Source: Section 220(3.1) of the Income Tax Act
Defendant_Response: Minister considered all relevant factors and acted reasonably
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to provide sufficient evidence of exceptional circumstances
Applicable_Process: Administrative discretion followed by judicial review
Governing_Rule: Section 220(3.1) of the Income Tax Act
